source.title: Mimesis  The Representation of Reality in Western Literature
source.title_without_series: Mimesis: The Representation of Reality in Western Literature
source.description: A half-century after its translation into English, Erich Auerbach's "Mimesis" still stands as a monumental achievement in literary criticism. A brilliant display of erudition, wit, and wisdom, his exploration of how great European writers from Homer to Virginia Woolf depicted reality has taught generations how to read Western literature. This new expanded edition includes a substantial essay in introduction by Edward Said as well as an essay, never before translated into English, in which Auerbach responds....

raw.author: Honoré de Balzac
contexts: The historical trajectory that is the spine of Mimesis is the passage from the separation of styles in classical antiquity, to their mingling in the New Testament, their first great climax in Dante’s Divine Comedy, and their ultimate apotheosis in the French realistic authors of the nineteenth century — Stendhal, Balzac, Flaubert, and then Proust.
Let us pause here for a moment and think of the nineteenth-century realists, of Balzac or Flaubert, of Tolstoi or Dostoevski. Old Grandet (in Eugénie Grandet)...

Another writer of the romantic generation, Balzac, who had as great a creative gift and far more closeness to reality, seized upon the representation of contemporary life as his own particular task and, together with Stendhal, can be regarded as the creator of modern realism.
He has found an attitude toward the reality of contemporary life which is entirely different from earlier attitudes and stylistic levels, including—and especially—Balzac’s and Stendhal’s.
In regard to the most important men of the romantic generation, to Victor Hugo and Balzac, that is, these questions must be answered in the affirmative.
In this respect only Balzac can be compared with him; but Balzac wrote at a time when much of what Zola saw had not yet developed or was not yet discernible.

His purpose was to comprise—as Balzac had done, but much more methodically and painstakingly—the whole life of the period (the Second Empire): the people of Paris, the rural population, the theater, the department stores, the stock exchange, and very much more besides.

Goethe or Keller, Dickens or Meredith, Balzac or Zola told us out of their certain knowledge what their characters did, what they felt and thought while doing it, and how their actions and thoughts were to be interpreted.
commentaries: The author lists Balzac as one of the French realistic authors representing the apotheosis of the stylistic trajectory traced in 'Mimesis'.

The author cites Balzac as a creator of modern realism, highlighting his focus on contemporary life and his partnership with Stendhal in this endeavor.
The author positions Flaubert's 'objective seriousness' as a stylistic departure from the approaches of earlier realists like Balzac and Stendhal.
The author references Balzac as a key figure of the romantic generation who overcame the tendency to flee reality and demonstrated an admirable instinct for diagnosing the times.
The author compares Zola to Balzac, noting Balzac wrote before the full development of the social issues Zola addressed.
The author compares Zola's encyclopedic literary project to Balzac's earlier attempt to capture the totality of contemporary society.
The author cites Balzac as an example of an earlier writer who narrated with objective certainty about characters.

raw.author: Petronius Arbiter
contexts: One is to be found in the book’s second chapter, “Fortunata,” whose starting point is a passage by the Roman author Petronius, followed by another by Tacitus.
This passage is taken from Petronius’ romance, of which only one episode—the banquet at the house of the wealthy freedman Trimalchio—is extant in full.

In Petronius’ book the highly practical and mundane, or what we may call the intrahistorical, concept of the instability of fortune, predominates; the account which Trimalchio gives of his rise to wealth is entirely practical and mundane, and there are similar passages elsewhere.

Hence, behind the bustle which Petronius sets before us, we sense nothing which might help us understand the action in terms of its economic and political context; and the historical movement, of which we spoke above, is here only a surface movement.

However vast the difference between the two passages here considered—the talk of the dinner guest in Petronius and the Pannonian mutiny in Tacitus—both reveal the limits of antique realism and thus of antique historical consciousness.

He does not mention the attempts at a history of manners which had been made from the eighteenth century on (Voltaire); hence there is no analysis setting forth the distinction between his presentation of manners and that of his possible predecessors; only Petronius is named.
commentaries: The author notes that Auerbach's analysis begins with a passage from Petronius.
The author cites Petronius as the author of a romance from which an excerpt is provided, specifically mentioning the episode of Trimalchio's banquet as a surviving example.
The author analyzes Petronius's work, 'The Banquet' (Satyricon), as a key example of ancient realism that focuses on the mundane and intrahistorical movement of fortune.
The author references Petronius as a realist of antiquity whose work lacks historical and economic depth.
The author references a passage from Petronius, contrasting it with Tacitus, to illustrate the defining limits of antique realism and historical consciousness.
The author notes that, in his discussion, Balzac names only Petronius among possible predecessors in the history of manners.

raw.title: Die antike Kunstprosa
raw.author: Eduard Norden
contexts: So Norden writes in his Antike Kunstprosa (2, 647): “We must bear in mind that the historians of antiquity did not attain, and indeed did not seek to attain, a presentation of general, world-moving ideas.”
commentaries: The author cites Norden's book to support the point that ancient historians did not aim to present overarching, world-moving ideas.

goodreads_match.title: Die antike Kunstprosa
goodreads_match.description: A foundational work on the history of artistic prose in antiquity, tracing its development from early Greek literature through the Hellenistic period and into Roman literature.

raw.title: Enarrationes in Psalmos
raw.author: Augustine of Hippo
contexts: It occurs in the Enarrationes in Psalmos and refers to the words, suscipiens mansuetos Dominus, in Psalm 146: Conticescant humanae voces, requiescant humanae cogitationes; ad incomprehensibilia non se extendant quasi comprehensuri, sed tamquam participaturi—a passage in which we see a most beautiful fusion of mystic elements and the concretely sensuous desire to share in possession (in opposition, of course, to the “proud” intellectual arrogance of those who insist on understanding).
commentaries: The author references Augustine's 'Enarrationes in Psalmos' to illustrate a mystical and participatory approach to understanding Scripture, contrasting it with intellectual pride.

goodreads_match.title: Enarrationes in Psalmos
goodreads_match.description: A collection of commentaries on the Psalms by Augustine of Hippo, written over several decades beginning around 392 AD. These exegetical works combine theological interpretation, pastoral guidance, and mystical reflection.

raw.author: Salimbene de Adam
contexts: that of Fra Salimbene de Adam, a Franciscan and the extremely gifted author of a Latin chronicle
commentaries: The author identifies Salimbene de Adam as the author of a Latin chronicle, using him as an example of a writer whose style possessed greater sensory force than written Italian of the time.

raw.title: The Origins of Historism
raw.author: Friedrich Meinecke
contexts: Friedrich Meinecke’s book on the origins of Historism (Munich and Berlin, 1936) is the finest and most mature treatment I know.
commentaries: The author praises Friedrich Meinecke's book as the finest and most mature scholarly treatment on the origins of Historism.

goodreads_match.title: Die Entstehung des Historismus
goodreads_match.description: Meinecke's seminal work on the development of historicism (Historismus) in Western thought, tracing its origins from the 18th century through Goethe's era.
